os_setup.description: Setup operating system with required tools and configurations

hello.description: Simple test function that prints hello from hostname

login.params: lambda args: {'name': args.session_name or 'CLI Session', '2FACode': args.tfa_code, 'requestedPermissions': args.permissions, 'tokenExpirationHours': args.expiration, 'target': getattr(args, 'target', None)}

help.description: Create a new company account with admin user
help.details: Creates a new Rediacc company along with its admin user account. The email and password parameters are used to create the admin user who will own the company. This is typically the first step in setting up a new Rediacc deployment.

examples.command: rediacc-cli create company 'Enterprise Inc' --email admin@enterprise.com --plan ELITE

help.notes: The admin user is automatically activated and becomes the company owner. Activation codes are provided by Rediacc sales.

user.params: lambda args: {'newUserEmail': args.email, 'newUserHash': pwd_hash(args.password), 'activationCode': args.activation_code or TEST_ACTIVATION_CODE}

help.description: Create a new user in your company
help.details: Creates a new user account that can access the company resources. Users must be activated before they can log in.

password.description: User's password (will be prompted if not provided)

examples.description: Create user and prompt for password

help.notes: New users must be activated using 'rediacc-cli user activate' before they can log in. Company admins can provide activation codes.

help.description: Create a new team in your company
help.details: Teams are organizational units that own machines, repositories, and other resources. Team members can manage all resources within the team.

vault.description: JSON object with team configuration (SSH keys, settings)

examples.description: Create team with vault configuration from file

help.notes: Team creation counts against your subscription limits. The creator automatically becomes a team member.

help.description: Create a new region for organizing bridges
help.details: Regions are logical or geographic groupings for bridges. They help organize infrastructure deployment across different locations or environments. Bridges must be associated with a region.

name.description: Unique name for the region (e.g., us-east, europe-west)

vault.description: JSON configuration for the region (provider settings, metadata)

help.notes: Regions cannot be deleted if they contain bridges. Region names must be unique across the company.

bridge.params: lambda args: {'regionName': args.region, 'bridgeName': args.name, 'bridgeVault': get_vault_data(args) or '{}'}

help.description: Create a new bridge for task processing
help.details: Bridges are autonomous queue processors that poll for tasks and execute them on machines via SSH. They run in bridge mode and can process multiple queue items in parallel. Each bridge must belong to a region.

region.description: Region where the bridge will be created

vault.description: JSON configuration for the bridge (batch size, timeout settings)

examples.description: Create bridge with custom batch size

help.notes: After creation, start the bridge with './bridge --bridge-mode token=<token> api_url=<url> master_password=<pwd>'. Use 'rediacc-cli login --target bridge-name' to get a bridge-specific token.

machine.params: lambda args: {'teamName': args.team, 'bridgeName': args.bridge, 'machineName': args.name, 'machineVault': get_vault_data(args) or '{}'}

help.description: Create a new machine in a team
help.details: Machines are remote servers that execute tasks via SSH. They must be associated with a team and connected through a bridge. Machine names must be unique across the entire company.

team.description: Team that will own this machine

bridge.description: Bridge to connect through (must exist in a region)

vault.description: JSON with machine config (ip, user, ssh_port, datastore)

examples.command: rediacc-cli create machine production-team us-east-bridge web-01
rediacc-cli create machine prod us-bridge db-01 --vault '{"ip":"10.0.0.10"}'

help.notes: You must be a member of the team. The bridge must exist and be accessible. Machine creation counts against subscription limits.

repository.params: lambda args: {'teamName': args.team, 'repoName': args.name, 'repoVault': get_vault_data(args) or '{}'}

help.description: Create a new repository for code and data storage
help.details: Repositories are isolated environments for storing code, data, or applications. They support Docker-based deployments via Rediaccfile, have dedicated storage volumes, and can be synchronized across machines.

team.description: Team that will own this repository

name.description: Unique name for the repository within the team

examples.description: Create repository with size and backup configuration

help.notes: Repository names must be unique within a team. After creation, deploy code using 'rediacc sync' or manage with queue functions like 'repo_new', 'repo_up', etc.

storage.params: lambda args: {'teamName': args.team, 'storageName': args.name, 'storageVault': get_vault_data(args) or '{}'}

help.description: Create a new storage resource
help.details: Storage resources represent external storage systems like S3 buckets, Azure Blob Storage, or network shares. They're used for backups, archives, and data exchange between systems.

team.description: Team that will own this storage

name.description: Unique name for the storage within the team

vault.description: JSON with storage credentials and configuration

vault-file.description: File containing JSON vault configuration with credentials

examples.command: rediacc-cli create storage prod azure-backup --vault-file azure-config.json
examples.description: Create Azure storage with credentials from file

help.notes: Storage credentials are encrypted in the vault. Supported types include S3, Azure Blob, GCS, SFTP, and SMB. Used with 'repo_push' and 'repo_pull' queue functions.

schedule.params: lambda args: {'teamName': args.team, 'scheduleName': args.name, 'scheduleVault': get_vault_data(args) or '{}'}

help.description: Create a scheduled task
help.details: Schedules automatically create queue items at specified intervals. They support cron expressions, time zones, and can be configured to run specific functions on target machines.

team.description: Team that will own this schedule

name.description: Unique name for the schedule within the team

vault.description: JSON with schedule configuration (cron, function, target)

help.notes: Schedules require Premium or Elite subscription. Cron expressions follow standard format. Schedule execution creates queue items with configured priority.

queue-item.params: lambda args: {'teamName': args.team, 'machineName': args.machine, 'bridgeName': args.bridge, 'queueVault': get_vault_data(args) or '{}', 'priority': getattr(args, 'priority', 3)}
queue-item.success_msg: Successfully created queue item for machine {machine} with priority {priority}

help.description: Create a queue item for task execution
help.details: Queue items represent tasks to be executed on machines by bridges. The bridge polls for items, executes them on the target machine via SSH, and reports results back.

bridge.description: Bridge to process this queue item

vault.description: JSON with task configuration and parameters

examples.command: rediacc-cli create queue-item prod web-01 us-bridge --priority 3
rediacc-cli create queue-item prod db-01 bridge-01 --priority 1 --vault-file task.json
examples.description: Create high priority item with task config

help.notes: Priority 1-2 requires Premium/Elite subscription. Community/Advanced limited to priority 3-5. You must be a team member.

help.description: List all teams in your company
help.details: Displays teams with membership information, resource counts, and vault access. Only shows vault data for teams where you are a member.

examples.description: List all teams in table format
List all teams in JSON format for scripting

help.notes: Requires authentication. Vault content is only visible for teams you belong to.

help.description: List all regions in your company
help.details: Shows geographic regions where you can deploy bridges and infrastructure. Each region can contain multiple bridges for distributed task processing.

examples.description: Display all regions with their vault configurations

help.notes: Regions define geographic or logical boundaries for infrastructure deployment.

help.description: List bridges in a specific region
help.details: Bridges are autonomous queue processors that execute tasks on machines. They poll for queue items and manage SSH connections to target machines.

region.description: Name of the region to list bridges from

examples.description: List all bridges in the us-east region

help.notes: Bridges must be running in bridge mode to process queue items.

help.description: List all users in your company
help.details: Shows all user accounts including their email, status (active/inactive), permission groups, 2FA status, and last login information. Useful for user management and audit purposes.

examples.description: Display all company users in table format

examples.command: rediacc-cli list users --output json | jq '.[] | select(.isActive == false)'

help.notes: Requires authentication. Shows user status, permissions, and security settings. Personal information like passwords is never exposed.

help.description: List active sessions and authentication requests
help.details: Shows all active authentication sessions including session names, creation time, expiration, permissions, and originating IP addresses. Helps monitor access and detect unauthorized sessions.

examples.command: rediacc-cli list sessions --output json | jq '.[] | select(.sessionName | contains("CLI"))'

help.notes: Sessions expire based on tokenExpirationHours setting. Bridge tokens may have extended expiration. Use 'logout' to terminate current session.

help.description: Display company resource limits and current usage
help.details: Shows your subscription limits and current usage for all resource types including teams, machines, bridges, repositories, and more. Multiple subscriptions stack their limits.

examples.description: View resource usage vs limits in table format
Extract resource limits data for monitoring

help.notes: Useful for capacity planning and monitoring when approaching subscription limits. Returns 402 Payment Required when limits are exceeded.

help.description: Show subscription details and billing information
help.details: Displays active subscriptions, plan details, expiration dates, and feature limits. Multiple subscriptions stack their resource limits. Shows both current usage and available capacity.
help.notes: Plans: COMMUNITY (free), ADVANCED, PREMIUM, ELITE. Higher tiers offer more resources, priority levels, and features like schedules and distributed storage.

help.description: Display company infrastructure as a hierarchical graph
help.details: Shows the complete infrastructure topology including regions, bridges, teams, machines, and their relationships in a graph format.
help.notes: Useful for understanding infrastructure topology and dependencies. JSON output can be used with graph visualization tools.

help.description: View company-wide vault configuration
help.details: Displays the encrypted vault data stored at the company level. This typically contains global settings and shared credentials.
help.notes: Requires company admin permissions. Vault data is automatically decrypted if you have the master password configured.

help.description: Get dropdown/selection data for UI components
help.details: Provides lookup data used for dropdowns and selection lists in UI components. Returns teams, regions, bridges, machines, users, and other selectable resources based on your permissions.

examples.description: Get lookup data specific to queue creation

help.notes: Returns different data based on user permissions. Admins see all resources, regular users see only accessible resources.

help.description: Display which company the current user belongs to
help.details: Shows the company information for the currently authenticated user. Useful for verifying you're logged into the correct company account.
help.notes: Requires authentication. Shows company name and ID.

audit-logs.params: lambda args: {'startDate': getattr(args, 'start_date', None), 'endDate': getattr(args, 'end_date', None), 'entityFilter': getattr(args, 'entity_filter', None), 'maxRecords': getattr(args, 'max_records', None)}

help.description: View audit trail of system changes
help.details: Shows detailed audit logs of all system modifications including who made changes, when, and what was changed. Essential for compliance, security monitoring, and troubleshooting.

start-date.description: Start date for audit logs (ISO 8601 format)

end-date.description: End date for audit logs (ISO 8601 format)

examples.description: Get audit logs from specific date

help.notes: Audit logs are retained based on subscription tier. Includes create, update, delete operations and authentication events.

entity-history.params: lambda args: {'entity': args.entity_type, 'credential': args.credential, 'maxRecords': getattr(args, 'max_records', None)}

help.description: View change history for a specific entity
help.details: Shows the modification history for a specific entity (team, machine, user, etc.) identified by its credential GUID. Includes who made changes, when, and what was changed.

entity_type.description: Type of entity (Team, Machine, User, Region, Bridge, Repository, Storage, Schedule)

examples.description: View history for a specific machine
View last 50 changes to a team

help.notes: Get the credential from 'inspect' commands. History includes creates, updates, deletes, and vault changes.

help.description: List machines in a specific team
help.details: Shows all machines assigned to a team including their status, assigned bridge, vault configuration, and queue statistics. Machine names are unique across the company.

team.description: Team name to list machines from (comma-separated for multiple teams)

examples.description: List all machines in production team

help.notes: You must be a member of the team to see its machines. Shows queue count for each machine.

help.description: List members of a specific team
help.details: Shows all users who have access to a team's resources. Team members can manage all resources within the team.

team.description: Team name to list members from

examples.description: List all members of production team

help.notes: You must be a member of the team to view its membership. Shows email addresses and join dates.

help.description: List all repositories owned by a team
help.details: Shows all code repositories associated with a team. Repositories are isolated environments for storing code, data, or applications with Docker support.

team.description: Team name to list repositories from

examples.command: rediacc-cli list team-repositories prod --output json | jq '.[].repoName'
examples.description: Extract repository names from production team

help.notes: You must be a member of the team. Shows repository names, credentials, and vault status.

help.description: List scheduled tasks for a team
help.details: Shows all scheduled tasks (cron jobs) configured for a team. Schedules automatically create queue items at specified intervals.

team.description: Team name to list schedules from

examples.description: Get schedule details in JSON format

help.notes: Requires Premium or Elite subscription. Shows cron expressions, target machines, and functions. You must be a team member.

help.description: List storage resources for a team
help.details: Shows all external storage configurations for a team. Storage resources represent S3 buckets, Azure Blob Storage, or network shares used for backups and data exchange.

team.description: Team name to list storages from

examples.description: List all storage resources in data-team

examples.command: rediacc-cli list team-storages backup --output json | jq '.[] | select(.storageName | contains("s3"))'

help.notes: You must be a member of the team. Storage credentials are encrypted in vaults. Used with repo_push/repo_pull functions.

team.confirm_msg: Are you sure you want to delete team '{name}'? This will remove all resources in the team.

help.description: Delete a team and all its resources
help.details: Permanently removes a team and all associated resources including machines, repositories, storages, and schedules. This action cannot be undone.

name.description: Name of the team to delete

help.notes: WARNING: This cascades to all team resources. Ensure data is backed up. Requires team ownership or admin permissions.

machine.confirm_msg: Are you sure you want to delete machine '{name}' from team '{team}'?

help.description: Delete a machine from a team
help.details: Permanently removes a machine configuration. Does not affect the actual server, only removes it from the Rediacc system. Pending queue items will fail.
help.notes: Check for pending queue items before deletion. The actual server is not affected. Consider updating vault to mark as decommissioned instead of deleting.

bridge.confirm_msg: Are you sure you want to delete bridge '{name}' from region '{region}'?

help.description: Delete a bridge from a region
help.details: Removes a bridge configuration. Ensure no machines are assigned to this bridge and no queue items are pending. Running bridge processes should be stopped first.
help.notes: Cannot delete if machines are assigned. Reassign machines first using 'update machine-bridge'. Stop bridge process before deletion.

region.confirm_msg: Are you sure you want to delete region '{name}'? This will remove all bridges in the region.

help.description: Delete a region and all its bridges
help.details: Removes a region and cascades deletion to all bridges within it. Ensure no machines are assigned to bridges in this region. This is a destructive operation.
help.notes: WARNING: Cascades to all bridges in the region. Cannot delete if bridges have assigned machines. Clear all dependencies first.

repository.confirm_msg: Are you sure you want to delete repository '{name}' from team '{team}'?

storage.confirm_msg: Are you sure you want to delete storage '{name}' from team '{team}'?

schedule.confirm_msg: Are you sure you want to delete schedule '{name}' from team '{team}'?

queue-item.confirm_msg: Are you sure you want to delete queue item '{task_id}'?

reset-auth.confirm_msg: Are you sure you want to reset authorization for bridge '{name}'? This will generate new credentials.

help.description: Generate new bridge credentials
help.details: Resets the authentication credentials for a bridge. The running bridge process will need to be restarted with new credentials.
help.notes: Use when credentials are compromised. Requires bridge restart. Get new token with 'login --target bridge-name'.

help.description: Rename a team
help.details: Changes the name of an existing team. All resources remain associated with the team. References in scripts and configurations must be updated manually.
help.notes: Team renaming doesn't affect resources or memberships. Update any automation scripts that reference the old name.

help.description: Rename a region
help.details: Changes the name of an existing region. All bridges within the region remain associated. Update any scripts or configurations that reference the old name.
help.notes: Region names must be unique within the company. Bridges and their associations are preserved.

help.description: Rename a bridge
help.details: Changes the name of an existing bridge within a region. Machine assignments remain unchanged. Running bridge processes are not affected.

examples.command: rediacc-cli update bridge us-east bridge-01 main-bridge
rediacc-cli update bridge europe test-bridge prod-bridge

help.notes: Bridge names must be unique within a region. Update machine assignments if needed using 'update machine-bridge'.

help.description: Rename a machine
help.details: Changes the name of an existing machine. The new name must be unique across the entire company. Active queue items continue processing.

examples.command: rediacc-cli update machine prod web-01 web-server-01

help.notes: Machine names are globally unique. Update schedules and scripts that reference the old name.

help.description: Reassign a machine to a different bridge
help.details: Changes which bridge processes queue items for a machine. Useful for load balancing, maintenance, or moving machines between regions. Pending queue items remain with the original bridge.

examples.command: rediacc-cli update machine-bridge prod db-01 us-west-bridge
rediacc-cli update machine-bridge dev test-server local-bridge
examples.description: Reassign test server to local bridge

help.notes: New queue items will be processed by the new bridge. Existing items in PENDING state remain with original bridge. Consider queue state before reassigning.

help.description: Rename a repository
help.details: Changes the name of an existing repository within a team. Repository data and configurations are preserved. Update deployment scripts that reference the old name.

examples.command: rediacc-cli update repository dev webapp web-application
rediacc-cli update repository prod api-v1 api-v2

help.notes: Repository names must be unique within a team. Running containers are not affected. Update sync scripts and schedules.

repository-vault.params: lambda args: {'teamName': args.team, 'repoName': args.name, 'repoVault': get_vault_data(args) or '{}', 'vaultVersion': getattr(args, 'vault_version', 1)}

help.description: Update repository configuration vault
help.details: Updates the encrypted configuration data for a repository. Used to modify repository settings, environment variables, deployment configurations, and secrets.

examples.command: rediacc-cli update repository-vault prod api --vault-file new-config.json

help.notes: Vault data is encrypted. Changes may require repository restart. Use 'inspect repository' to see current vault.

help.description: Rename a storage resource
help.details: Changes the name of an existing storage configuration. The actual storage backend (S3 bucket, Azure container, etc.) is not affected.

examples.command: rediacc-cli update storage backup s3-temp s3-archive
rediacc-cli update storage data azure-test azure-prod

help.notes: Storage names must be unique within a team. Update backup scripts and schedules that reference the old name.

storage-vault.params: lambda args: {'teamName': args.team, 'storageName': args.name, 'storageVault': get_vault_data(args) or '{}', 'vaultVersion': getattr(args, 'vault_version', 1)}

help.description: Update storage credentials and configuration
help.details: Updates the encrypted vault containing storage credentials and settings. Used to change access keys, endpoints, or storage parameters.

vault.description: JSON with storage credentials and config

examples.command: rediacc-cli update storage-vault backup s3-main --vault-file new-creds.json

help.notes: Credentials are encrypted. Test access after updating. Supports S3, Azure Blob, GCS, SFTP, and SMB.

help.description: Rename a scheduled task
help.details: Changes the name of an existing schedule. The cron expression and task configuration remain unchanged.

examples.command: rediacc-cli update schedule ops backup-task daily-backup
rediacc-cli update schedule prod sync-v1 sync-v2

help.notes: Schedule names must be unique within a team. The schedule continues running with the new name.

schedule-vault.params: lambda args: {'teamName': args.team, 'scheduleName': args.name, 'scheduleVault': get_vault_data(args) or '{}', 'vaultVersion': getattr(args, 'vault_version', 1)}

help.description: Update schedule configuration
help.details: Updates the encrypted vault containing schedule settings including cron expression, target machine, function, and parameters.

examples.command: rediacc-cli update schedule-vault prod sync --vault-file new-schedule.json

help.notes: Requires Premium or Elite subscription. Changes take effect at next scheduled run. Use standard cron format.

help.description: Update the status of a machine
help.details: Sets a custom status message for a machine, useful for maintenance windows, debugging, or operational notes. The status is displayed in machine listings.

examples.command: rediacc-cli update machine-status prod db-01 'Maintenance mode - do not use'

help.notes: Status is free-form text. Use consistent conventions for automation. Requires team membership.

help.description: Update vault data for any resource type
help.details: Updates the encrypted vault configuration for teams, machines, regions, bridges, company, repositories, storages, or schedules. Vaults store sensitive configuration data and credentials.

file.description: File containing JSON vault data (use '-' for stdin)

team.description: Team name (required for machine, repository, storage, schedule)

examples.command: rediacc-cli vault set machine web-01 machine-config.json --team prod
echo '{"SSH_PRIVATE_KEY":"..."}' | rediacc-cli vault set team dev-team -

help.notes: Vault data is encrypted with master password. Always backup current vault before updating. Use 'inspect' commands to view current vault.

help.description: Set the master password for vault encryption
help.details: Configures the master password used to encrypt and decrypt all vault data. This password is stored locally and never transmitted. Required for vault operations.

examples.description: Set master password with secure prompt

help.notes: Password is stored in local configuration. Use a strong password. Required for viewing/updating vault data.

help.description: Clear the stored master password
help.details: Removes the master password from local configuration. You'll need to re-enter it for future vault operations.
help.notes: Use this for security when done with vault operations. Does not affect encrypted data.

help.description: Show vault encryption status
help.details: Displays whether a master password is configured and provides information about vault encryption status.
help.notes: Shows if master password is set but not the password itself.

create-cluster.params: lambda args: {'teamName': args.team, 'clusterName': args.name, 'clusterVault': get_vault_data(args) or '{}'}
create-cluster.success_msg: Successfully created distributed storage cluster: {name} for team {team}

help.description: Create a distributed storage cluster
help.details: Creates a cluster configuration for distributed storage across multiple machines. Enables redundant storage with automatic replication and failover.

team.description: Team that will own the cluster

help.notes: Requires Elite subscription. Add machines after creation. Cluster names must be unique within a team.

delete-cluster.confirm_msg: Are you sure you want to delete distributed storage cluster '{name}' from team '{team}'?

help.description: Delete a distributed storage cluster
help.details: Permanently removes a distributed storage cluster configuration. Does not delete data on machines, only the cluster configuration.
help.notes: Remove all machines from cluster first. Data on machines is preserved. This action cannot be undone.

help.description: Get details of a specific storage cluster
help.details: Shows detailed information about a distributed storage cluster including configuration, member machines, and health status.

examples.command: rediacc-cli distributed-storage get-cluster data replicated-storage --output json
examples.description: Get cluster info in JSON format

help.notes: Shows machine membership, replication status, and storage utilization. Requires team membership.

help.description: List all storage clusters for a team
help.details: Shows all distributed storage clusters owned by a team including their status and machine counts.

team.description: Team name to list clusters from

examples.command: rediacc-cli distributed-storage list-clusters data --output json | jq '.[] | select(.status == "HEALTHY")'

help.notes: Elite subscription feature. Shows cluster health, machine count, and storage capacity.

add-machines.success_msg: Successfully added machines to distributed storage cluster: {cluster}

help.description: Add machines to a storage cluster
help.details: Adds one or more machines as storage nodes to a distributed storage cluster. Machines must have sufficient storage capacity.

examples.command: rediacc-cli distributed-storage add-machines storage-team main-cluster storage-01,storage-02
rediacc-cli distributed-storage add-machines data backup-cluster storage-03

help.notes: Machines must be in the same team. Triggers data rebalancing. Monitor cluster health after adding.

remove-machines.confirm_msg: Are you sure you want to remove machines from cluster '{cluster}'?
remove-machines.success_msg: Successfully removed machines from distributed storage cluster: {cluster}

help.description: Remove machines from a storage cluster
help.details: Removes machines from a distributed storage cluster. Data is migrated to remaining nodes before removal.

examples.command: rediacc-cli distributed-storage remove-machines storage-team main-cluster storage-01
rediacc-cli distributed-storage remove-machines data backup old-node-01,old-node-02 --force

help.notes: Ensure sufficient capacity remains. Data migration may take time. Monitor cluster during rebalancing.

update-status.success_msg: Successfully updated distributed storage cluster status: {cluster}

help.description: Update cluster operational status
help.details: Changes the operational status of a distributed storage cluster. Used for maintenance or to control cluster availability.

examples.command: rediacc-cli distributed-storage update-status storage-team main-cluster MAINTENANCE
rediacc-cli distributed-storage update-status data backup-cluster ONLINE

help.notes: OFFLINE prevents new writes. MAINTENANCE allows reads but not writes. Monitor cluster health after status changes.

update-vault.params: lambda args: {'teamName': args.team, 'clusterName': args.cluster, 'clusterVault': get_vault_data(args) or '{}', 'vaultVersion': getattr(args, 'vault_version', 1)}
update-vault.success_msg: Successfully updated distributed storage cluster vault: {cluster}

help.description: Update cluster configuration vault
help.details: Updates the encrypted configuration for a distributed storage cluster including replication settings, storage policies, and performance parameters.

examples.command: rediacc-cli distributed-storage update-vault data backup --vault-file new-cluster-config.json

help.notes: Changes may require cluster restart. Some settings trigger data rebalancing. Elite subscription required.

help.description: Create a new permission group
help.details: Creates a permission group that can be assigned to users. Permission groups control access to API endpoints and system features.

name.description: Unique name for the permission group

help.notes: Requires admin permissions. Group names must be unique within the company. Add permissions after creation.

delete-group.confirm_msg: Are you sure you want to delete permission group '{name}'?

help.description: Delete a permission group
help.details: Permanently removes a permission group. Users assigned to this group will lose those permissions.
help.notes: Cannot delete system groups. Check user assignments before deletion. This is irreversible.

help.description: Add permission to a group
help.details: Grants a specific API endpoint permission to a permission group. Users in the group gain access to that endpoint.

examples.description: Allow read-only users to list machines

help.notes: Permission names correspond to API endpoints. Use 'list lookup-data' to see available permissions.

remove.confirm_msg: Are you sure you want to remove permission '{name}' from group '{group}'?

help.description: Remove permission from a group
help.details: Revokes a specific API endpoint permission from a permission group. Users in the group lose access to that endpoint.
help.notes: Takes effect immediately for all users in the group. Use 'list-group' to see current permissions.

assign.success_msg: Successfully assigned permission group {group} to user {email}

help.description: Assign permission group to user
help.details: Changes a user's permission group, granting them all permissions associated with that group. Users can only belong to one permission group.
help.notes: Replaces user's current permission group. Changes take effect on next login. Requires admin permissions.

help.description: List all permission groups
help.details: Shows all permission groups in the company including system groups and custom groups. Displays group names and member counts.
help.notes: System groups like 'Admins' and 'Bridges' cannot be modified. Shows user count for each group.

help.description: Show permissions in a specific group
help.details: Lists all API endpoint permissions granted to a permission group. Shows which operations users in this group can perform.
help.notes: Permission names correspond to API endpoints. Compare groups to understand access levels.

block-user-requests.success_msg: Successfully updated company user request blocking: {block}

update-vault.params: lambda args: {'companyVault': get_vault_data(args) or '{}', 'vaultVersion': getattr(args, 'vault_version', None)}

help.description: Bulk update multiple company vaults
help.details: Updates multiple vault configurations at once. Useful for restoring from backup or migrating settings.
help.notes: Requires admin permissions. Use with caution as it replaces all vault data. Always backup first.

trace.params: lambda args: {'entity': args.entity_type, 'credential': args.credential, 'maxRecords': getattr(args, 'max_records', None)}

help.description: Get detailed audit trail for entity
help.details: Retrieves comprehensive audit information for a specific entity including all changes, access logs, and related operations.

entity_type.description: Type of entity (Team, Machine, User, Region, Bridge)

examples.description: Get full audit trail for machine
Get last 50 audit entries for user

help.notes: More detailed than entity-history. Includes access logs, failed attempts, and related entity changes.

activate.params: lambda args: {'userEmail': args.email, 'activationCode': args.code or TEST_ACTIVATION_CODE}

help.description: Activate a user account
help.details: Activates a newly created user account using an activation code. Users must be activated before they can log in. Default code is 111111 for testing.

email.description: Email address of user to activate

help.notes: No authentication required for activation. Activation codes are set during user creation. Users receive activation instructions via email if configured.

deactivate.confirm_msg: Are you sure you want to deactivate user '{email}'?

help.description: Change your password
help.details: Updates the password for the currently authenticated user. The new password is hashed before transmission. You'll need to re-authenticate after changing.

new-password.description: New password (will be prompted if not provided)

help.notes: Requires current authentication. Password requirements depend on company policy. After change, all sessions are invalidated - you must log in again.

update-2fa.params: lambda args: {'enable': args.enable, 'userHash': pwd_hash(args.password), 'currentCode': getattr(args, 'current_code', None)}

help.description: Configure two-factor authentication
help.details: Enables or disables two-factor authentication for your account. When enabling, you'll receive a QR code to scan with your authenticator app. When disabling, you need your current 2FA code.
help.notes: Use authenticator apps like Google Authenticator or Authy. Save backup codes when enabling. 2FA adds security but is required for some operations.

help.description: Check authentication request status
help.details: Queries the status of a pending authentication request by its hash. Used to verify if an authentication attempt succeeded.
help.notes: Request hashes are provided during login attempts. Status includes pending, authorized, or expired.

help.description: Grant special privileges to auth request
help.details: Elevates an authentication request with special privileges. Used for administrative operations requiring enhanced permissions.
help.notes: Requires existing admin permissions. Use with caution. Privileges are temporary for the session.

help.description: Add user to team
help.details: Grants a user membership in a team, giving them access to all team resources including machines, repositories, and storages.
help.notes: User must exist and be activated. You must be a team member to add others. Changes take effect immediately.

remove.confirm_msg: Are you sure you want to remove '{email}' from team '{team}'?

help.description: Remove user from team
help.details: Revokes a user's team membership, removing their access to all team resources. The user remains in the company.
help.notes: Cannot remove last team member. User loses access immediately. Consider impact on active work.

list.params: lambda args: {'teamName': getattr(args, 'team', None), 'machineName': getattr(args, 'machine', None), 'bridgeName': getattr(args, 'bridge', None), 'status': getattr(args, 'status', None), 'priority': getattr(args, 'priority', None), 'minPriority': getattr(args, 'min_priority', None), 'maxPriority': getattr(args, 'max_priority', None), 'dateFrom': getattr(args, 'date_from', None), 'dateTo': getattr(args, 'date_to', None), 'taskId': getattr(args, 'task_id', None), 'includeCompleted': getattr(args, 'include_completed', True), 'includeCancelled': getattr(args, 'include_cancelled', True), 'onlyStale': getattr(args, 'only_stale', False), 'staleThresholdMinutes': getattr(args, 'stale_threshold', None), 'maxRecords': getattr(args, 'max_records', None)}

help.description: List queue items with various filters
help.details: View queue items across teams with powerful filtering options. Monitor task status, find stuck items, analyze performance, and track execution history.

examples.description: Find items stuck for over an hour
Show high priority items for production

help.notes: Default includes all statuses. Stale detection helps find stuck items. Use date filters for historical analysis.

cancel.confirm_msg: Are you sure you want to cancel queue item '{task_id}'?

help.description: Cancel a pending or processing queue item
help.details: Marks a queue item as cancelled, preventing further processing. If already processing, the bridge will attempt to stop execution gracefully. Completed items cannot be cancelled.
help.notes: Cancellation is immediate for PENDING items. PROCESSING items may continue briefly while the bridge stops gracefully. Check status after cancelling.

help.description: Retry a failed queue item
help.details: Creates a new queue item with the same configuration as a failed item. The original item's status remains FAILED. Useful for transient failures or after fixing issues.

task_id.description: Task ID (GUID) of failed item to retry

examples.command: rediacc-cli queue list --status FAILED --output json | jq -r '.[].taskId' | xargs -I {} rediacc-cli queue retry {}

help.notes: Only FAILED items can be retried. Creates a new item with same priority and configuration. Check failure reason before retrying to avoid repeated failures.

machine.filter: lambda data, args: [m for m in data if m.get('machineName') == args.name]

repository.filter: lambda data, args: [r for r in data if r.get('repoName') == args.name]

help.description: Get detailed info about a repository
help.details: Shows comprehensive information about a specific repository including vault configuration, size, and settings.

examples.command: rediacc-cli inspect repository prod api --output json

help.notes: Shows decrypted vault if master password is set. Includes size, type, and configuration details.

login.name: --target
login.help: Target resource (e.g., bridge name for bridge token)

queue-item.name: --priority
queue-item.help: Priority level (1=highest, 5=lowest, default=3). Premium/Elite subscriptions only.

audit-logs.name: --start-date
audit-logs.help: Start date for audit logs (ISO format)

audit-logs.name: --end-date
audit-logs.help: End date for audit logs (ISO format)

audit-logs.name: --entity-filter
audit-logs.help: Filter by entity type (e.g., Team, Machine, User)

audit-logs.name: --max-records
audit-logs.help: Maximum number of records to retrieve (default: 1000)

entity-history.name: entity_type
entity-history.help: Entity type (e.g., Team, Machine, User, Region, Bridge)

entity-history.name: --max-records
entity-history.help: Maximum number of records to retrieve (default: 500)

set.name: file
set.help: File containing JSON vault data (or - for stdin)

set.name: --team
set.help: Team name (for machine, repository, storage, schedule)

update-2fa.name: enable
update-2fa.type: lambda x: bool(int(x) if x in ['0', '1'] else x.lower() == 'true')

list.name: --date-from
list.help: Filter by date range start (ISO format)

list.name: --date-to
list.help: Filter by date range end (ISO format)

trace.name: entity_type
trace.help: Entity type (e.g., Team, Machine, User, Region, Bridge)

trace.name: --max-records
trace.help: Maximum number of records to retrieve

status.name: request_hash
status.help: Request hash to check status for
